definition:
HyperText Markup Language, used to structure content on the web, e.g., tags like

and

An HTML element, like

or , used to define content structure
Additional information in an HTML tag, like class or id, e.g.,
HTML elements that convey meaning, like <article> or <nav>, improving accessibility
A block-level HTML element, <div>, used as a container for other elements
An inline HTML element, <span>, used to style or group small portions of content
An attribute for tags, providing text descriptions for accessibility, e.g., alt='logo'
The tag, used for hyperlinks, e.g., Link
An HTML element, <form>, for collecting user input, e.g., text fields and buttons
An HTML tag, <meta>, for metadata like character encoding or viewport settings
Cascading Style Sheets, used to style and format web content, e.g., colors, fonts
A CSS pattern to target elements, e.g., .class, #id, or element names like p
A CSS concept describing an element’s padding, border, margin, and content
A layout system for arranging elements in rows or columns, using properties like justify-content
A CSS layout system for two-dimensional arrangements, using rows and columns
A CSS technique for responsive design, applying styles based on device properties, e.g., @media (max-width: 600px)
A CSS keyword for styling specific states, e.g., :hover for mouse-over effects
A CSS property for smooth style changes, e.g., color or size, over time
A CSS unit relative to the root font size, e.g., 1rem = 16px if root is 16px
The CSS rule determining which style applies when multiple rules target an element
A programming language for dynamic web content, e.g., interactivity and animations
A named storage for data in JavaScript, declared with let, const, or var
A reusable block of JavaScript code, defined with function or arrow syntax, e.g., () => {}
A JavaScript method to handle user actions, e.g., addEventListener('click', callback)
Document Object Model, a tree-like representation of a webpage, manipulated by JavaScript
A JavaScript data structure for ordered lists, e.g., [1, 2, 3], with methods like .map()
A JavaScript data structure for key-value pairs, e.g., { name: 'John' }
JavaScript syntax for handling asynchronous operations, simplifying promises
A JavaScript function that retains access to its outer scope’s variables
A JavaScript object representing an asynchronous operation’s eventual result
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, using components and hooks
A runtime for executing JavaScript server-side, enabling backend development
Node Package Manager, a tool for managing JavaScript libraries and dependencies
A module bundler for JavaScript, optimizing assets like code, images, and styles
A progressive JavaScript framework for building interactive web interfaces
A TypeScript-based framework for building dynamic web applications
A CSS preprocessor adding features like variables, nesting, and mixins
A superset of JavaScript adding static types, improving code reliability
A tool for identifying and fixing JavaScript code issues, enforcing style rules
A fast build tool and development server for modern web projects
Representational State Transfer, an API design style using HTTP methods like GET, POST
Application Programming Interface, enabling data exchange between systems, e.g., fetching JSON
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing, a security mechanism controlling resource access across domains
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight format for data exchange, e.g., { 'key': 'value' }
HyperText Transfer Protocol, the foundation for data communication on the web
Designing websites to be usable by people with diverse abilities, e.g., screen readers
Search Engine Optimization, improving a website’s visibility on search engines
Designing websites to adapt to different screen sizes, e.g., mobile, tablet, desktop
A system to track and manage code changes, e.g., Git and GitHub
A web app with native app-like features, e.g., offline access, push notifications
